bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: William Roger Coleman was a longtime Brooklyn resident who lived during the 19th and 20th centuries. According to accounts of his grandson (also named William R. Coleman), the elder Coleman was brought to an orphanage on Staten Island at the age of four by a woman named Janny Coleman, who claimed to be his mother. Wiliam was raised at the orphanage until his early teens, when he was sent on an orphan train to Hutchinson, KS. In his mid-teens, he returned to New York and settled in Brooklyn, working as a clerk on the piers. At some point during his teenage years he had also attended Mt. Herman School in Northfield, MA for at least one year. Later, Coleman worked as a salesman of automobile parts for a firm called Aero Tire & Supply Co. on the West Side of Manhattan. In 1898, Coleman enlisted in the Army and fought in the Spanish-American War as a member of the Rough Riders, Private Troop H, 1st Cavalry. In the early 1900s, Coleman worked as a social worker at one of the Settlement houses on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, working with Jewish gang members. It was through this capacity that he met Sophie Sekoson, his future wife, who was also Jewish. They were married after a long courtship, and Coleman reportedly converted to Judaism.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Gift of William R. Coleman, Esquire, 1992, 1996, 2000, and 2006.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The William R. Coleman collection spans the period 1891 to 1937 and consists of personal documents, correspondence, memorabilia, and photographs documenting Coleman's life. Additional items include a wedding notice, calling cards and business cards, autobiographical sketches, a pocket diary, and items pertaining to Coleman's service in the military, including a publication entitled The Soldier Handbook and discharge papers from the Spanish-American War. Finally, the collection also includes a typescript screenplay by Albert St. Louis pertaining to the kidnapping case of Charles Ross, in which Coleman's alleged mother, Janny Coleman, may have been indirectly involved. The screenplay was assembled from William R. Coleman's notes on the case.
